explanations.A: A is in the column of 4 and the row of 5, so the value in this square will be 5+4 which equals 9.
explanations.B: Look at the row and column B is in: the value in this square will be 4+4 which is not 9. Can you find two numbers here which add up to give 9?
explanations.C: Look at the row and column C is in: the value in this square will be 5+5 which is not 9. Can you find two numbers here which add up to give 9?
explanations.D: Look at the row and column D is in: the value in this square will be 3+4 which is not 9. Can you find two numbers here which add up to give 9?

explanations.A: A is in the column of 1 and the row of 2, so the value in this square will be 1 + 2 which equals 3.
explanations.B: Look at the row and column B is in: the value in this square will be 3 + 1 which is not 3. Can you find two numbers here which add up to give 3?
explanations.C: Look at the row and column C is in: the value in this square will be 1 + 3 which is not 3. Can you find two numbers here which add up to give 3?
explanations.D: Look at the row and column D is in: the value in this square will be 4 + 1 which is not 3. Can you find two numbers here which add up to give 3?

explanations.A: Even numbers are in the two times table, and the highlighted numbers 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 are all in the two times table, so this is true. Check the row and column each highlighted number is in, to see what is being added together.
explanations.B: The highlighted numbers 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 are all made by adding the same number, eg. 1+1=2, 2+2=4, so this is true. Which statement is not true about the numbers being added together?
explanations.C: The highlighted numbers 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 are all made by adding the same number, eg. 1+1=2, 2+2=4, so they are not made by adding odds and evens; this statement is not true.
explanations.D: The highlighted numbers 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 are all in the two times table, so this is true. Check the row and column each highlighted number is in, to see what is being added together.

explanations.A: These numbers are not in the two times table, maybe you're thinking of the notation we use.. 1x1 =1², 2x2=2²... What does that little 2 mean?
explanations.B: We are not adding the same number together, we are multiplying them... Look for the true statement
explanations.C: Not quite, the highlighted numbers are made by multiplying the same number together.. What type of numbers does this produce?!
explanations.D: The highlighted numbers 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36 are all made by multiplying the same number together, eg. 1x1=2, 2x2=4 and they are called square numbers!

explanations.A: If we move up a square we go into the previous row of 10, from 79 to 69. This is subtracting 10, so which direction would be adding 10?
explanations.B: If we move down a square we go into the next row of 10, from 79 to 89. This is the same as adding 10.
explanations.C: If we move left a square we stay in the same row of 10, going from 79 to 78. This is the same as subtracting 1. Which direction would be the same as adding 10?
explanations.D: If we move right a square we stay in the same row of 10, going from 79 to 80. This is the same as adding 1. Which direction would be the same as adding 10?

explanations.A: If we move up a square we go into the previous row of 10, from 53 to 43 so this is subtracting 10.
explanations.B: If we move down a square we go into the next row of 10, from 53 to 63, so this is the same as adding 10. Which direction would be subtracting 10?
explanations.C: If we move left a square we stay in the same row of 10, going from 53 to 52. This is the same as subtracting 1. In which direction do we need to go to subtract 10?
explanations.D: If we move right a square we stay in the same row of 10, going from 53 to 54. This is the same as adding 1. In which direction do we need to go to subtract 10?

explanations.A: All the numbers in the 4 times table are also in the 2 times table, so they are all even. This statement is true. Try using some examples to check each of the other statements.
explanations.B: The 6 times table is highlighted in green: 6, 12, 18, .... If we halve these we get 3, 6, 9, ... which is the 3 times table, not the 2 times table. This statement is not true.
explanations.C: The two times table is highlighted in red: 2, 4, 6,... If we double these we get 4, 8, 12,... which is the 4 times table. This statement is true. Try using examples like this to check the other statements.
explanations.D: If we add the red number (2 times table) and the yellow number (4 times table) in each column, we get 2+4 = 6, 4 + 8 = 12, 6+12 = 18, etc. which is the 6 times table. This statement is true. Try using examples like this to check the other statements.

explanations.A: The three times table is highlighted in purple: 3, 6, 9,... If we double these we get 6, 12, 18,... which is the 6 times table. This statement is true. Try using examples like this to check the other statements.
explanations.B: If we add the red number (2 times table) and the yellow number (4 times table) in each column, we get 2+4 = 6, 4 + 8 = 12, 6+12 = 18, etc. which is the 6 times table. This statement is true. Try using examples like this to check the other statements.
explanations.C: The 6 times table is highlighted in green: 6, 12, 18, .... If we halve these we get 3, 6, 9, ... which is the 3 times table so this statement is true. Check the other statements, which one is NOT true?
explanations.D: Looking at the three times table highlighted in purple: 3, 6, 9, 12 etc.. We can see 6 and 12 are part of it and these are even so this statement is not true.

explanations.A: Not quite - maybe you thought the middle row was the 6 times table, so you added 6 to 49. Actually 42 and 49 are in the 7 times table, so try adding 7.
explanations.B: Not quite - maybe you thought the middle row was the 8 times table, so you added 8 to 49. Actually 42 and 49 are in the 7 times table, so try adding 7.
explanations.C: Almost - you may have mixed up the answer to 7x8 and the answer to 6x9.
explanations.D: 42 and 49 are in the 7 times table, so we can add 7 to find the next number. 49 + 7 = 56. We can also check by putting 56 into the bottom row: 48, 56, 64 is part of the 8 times table.

explanations.A: Not quite - maybe you thought the middle row was the 5 times table, so you added 5 to 16. Actually 12 and 16 are in the 4 times table, so try adding 4.
explanations.B: Not quite - maybe you thought the middle row was the 3 times table, so you added 3 to 16. Actually 12 and 16 are in the 4 times table, so try adding 4.
explanations.C: 12 and 16 are in the 4 times table, so we can add 4 to find the next number. 16 + 4 = 20. We can also check by putting 20 into the bottom row: 15, 20, 25 is part of the 5 times table.
explanations.D: Almost - you may have mixed up the answer to 4x5 and the answer to 3x6.
